header_summary:
AdamISZ's analysis contrasts the robustness of Schnorr signatures against manipulations with the vulnerabilities of ECDSA signatures, explaining the mathematical impossibility of creating a valid new public key \(P2\) for a given message and signature tuple due to Schnorr's key-prefixing method. This discussion highlights the cryptographic strengths and weaknesses of each signature scheme, particularly in scenarios attempting to validate a signature with an alternate public key. The exploration delves into the technical nuances of digital signature algorithms, emphasizing their role in enhancing or compromising digital security practices. [More details](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/5fcbe15c-2793-44a7-88d1-e708c224f2fdn@googlegroups.com/T/#m040a0b9fa58cfa4b12044d5999343ebecf242535)

Morehouse's post uncovers a significant vulnerability in versions 0.0.125 and below of the Lightning Development Kit (LDK), prone to a liquidity griefing attack that could render funds unrecoverable without manual intervention. The flaw, rooted in the mishandling of conflicting HTLC claims on force-closed channels, was corrected in LDK version 0.1, emphasizing the importance of software auditing and the potential consequences of overlooked bugs in financial applications. The resolution and the proactive steps taken to address this vulnerability serve as a critical reminder of the ongoing challenges in securing cryptocurrency technologies and the necessity of continuous updates and code reviews. [Read more](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/disclosure-ldk-invalid-claims-liquidity-griefing/1400)

recent_posts.title: Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
recent_posts.summary:
- Schnorr signatures' key-prefixing prevents creating valid new public keys for existing tuples.
- ECDSA lacks key-prefixing, allowing theoretical public key recovery but faces practical challenges.
- The analysis contrasts Schnorr and ECDSA signatures, highlighting their security mechanisms against substitute public keys.

recent_posts.title: Disclosure: LDK Invalid Claims Liquidity Griefing
recent_posts.summary:
- A vulnerability in LDK pre-0.1 affects anchor channels via a liquidity griefing attack.
- The flaw arises from LDK's handling of conflicting HTLC claims, leading to locked funds.
- Fixing the issue requires updating to LDK 0.1 and replaying certain transactions for security.

active_posts.title: What happens after we "run out" of script flags?
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core codebase uses a 32-bit unsigned integer for script flags.
- Proposing 11 new script verification flags nears the system's capacity limit.
- Transitioning to a 64-bit representation could significantly expand capacity.
